A successful internship not only functions as a crucial bridge to entering the work force but also provides you with the raw material for your MA thesis.  Content Students practice and develop their research skills in a work environment. In the process, the develop a research question suitable for producing an MA thesis.

Career orientation:
training in written and oral presentation of research

Course goals During and after the course you: 
  • carry out a project at school and evaluate product as well as process,
  • work in a project-based way and carry out relevant analyses for the project
  • demonstrate an understanding of the character of the project and be able to identify the strengths and weaknesses for implementation
  • get in touch with client and target audiences in a proper way and maintain good relations
  • reflect on your own learning process
Content In this course you will get a general overview of the field of science education and its knowledge base, and you will implement that information during an internship at school. You will become acquainted with school as a work environment, carry out all kinds of relevant tasks, seek active contact with the target audience(s) and meanwhile work on a research & development project for the benefit of the school organization. The latter will be conducted using information and literature discussed during seminars. The concrete deliverables of the project are to be handed in and the end of the course. In addition, you  reflect on your own professional development by means of learning aims which you have set up for yourself at the start of the internship. 
 
Within given constraints, you will have to carry out a project that fits the wishes of the school. During the internship a planned way of working is very important. The seminars and lectures have the aim to scaffold your working. We will pay attention to, amongst others, instructional design theories, design tools and theories on change and innovation in (science) education. In addition, during the seminars the different school projects will be presented to enable collegial feedback and intervision.

course_title: Internship Social, health and organisational psychology, track Health Promotion
lecturers: ['A. van der Weiden', 'D.R. Marchiori', 'D.W.M. Gevers', 'dr. A.G. Venema', 'dr. C. Evers', 'dr. F.M. Kroese', 'dr. J.S. Benjamins', 'dr. M.A. Adriaanse', 'L.C. van Gestel, MSc', 'M. Gillebaart', 'prof. dr. D.T.D. de Ridder', 'S. Prinsen']
text:
Course goals
During your internship you will be working as a psychologist in one of the occupational or research fields in Health Psychology. The learning goals of the internship are the following:
 
  1. learning to apply knowledge and skills that you acquired in the field of Health Psychology
  2. further development of professional skills that are relevant to the field of HealthPsychology.
Professional and scientific reflection is an important aspect of these learning goals.

 
Correspondence between the evaluation and learning goals

The general and individual learning goals of the internship need to be addressed in an individual internship report and during performance appraisals by the supervisor in the internship organisation. The grade for the internship is based on the individual internship report, the performance of the student, and reflection of the student on his/her internship activities. To this end, the internal supervisor (staff member of the SHOP department) will consult the external supervisor in the organisation.
Content
Students can choose between a practical internship, a research internship, or a combination of both. Most students opt for a practical internship in an organisation. In a practical internship, the main purpose is to familiarise oneself with the health-related practice in the field, varying from working with behavior-specialist and consultants, to researchers, trainers, coaches, and managers on health-related projects. The purpose of a research internship is to conduct research in the field of Health Psychology. A research internship can be performed at the university or in an organization or scientific research institute. Moreover, students can choose for a training internship at the university, in which they are trained to work as a work group teacher in a bachelor course on communication skills.
 
Internships are supervised in the organisation by a professional (in principle, a Health Psychologist) who is expert in the activities to be performed. Students also receive supervision from a staff member of the SHOP department. It is recommended to combine the internship with the thesis. We also advise students to start their search for an internship as early as possible and to look actively for internships on the internet, through networking, and on Blackboard. The regulations concerning the internship can be found on Blackboard. Further information about internships can be obtained via the coordinator of the master track Health Promotion, Catharine Evers, PhD.. She can be contacted via c.evers@uu.nl.

text:
Course goals During the internship students work as a psychologist in one of the occupational or research fields in Social Psychology. The learning goals of the internship are the following:
  1. learning to apply knowledge and skills that are acquired in the field of Social Psychology
  2. further development of professional skills that are relevant to the field of Social Psychology.
Professional and scientific reflection is an important aspect of these learning goals.
 
Correspondence between the evaluation and learning goals

The general and individual learning goals of the internship are addressed in an individual internship report and during performance appraisals by the supervisor in the internship organisation. The grade for the internship is based on the individual internship report, the performance of the student, and reflection of the student on his/her internship activities.   Content Students can choose between a practical internship, a research internship, or a combination of both. Most students opt for a practical internship in an organisation. Moreover, students can choose for a training internship at the university, whereby they are trained to become a trainer in professional communication skills.
 
Internships are supervised in the organisation by a professional (in principle, a Social Psychologist) who is expert in the activities to be performed. text:
Course goals During your internship you will be working as a psychologist in one of the occupational or research fields in Work and Organisational Psychology. The learning goals of the internship are the following:
1.       learning to apply knowledge and skills that you acquired in the field of Work and Organisational Psychology
2.       further development of professional skills that are relevant to the field of Work and Organisational Psychology.
Professional and scientific reflection is hereby an important aspect.
 
Correspondence between the evaluation and learning goals

The general and individual learning goals of the internship need to be addressed in an individual internship report and during performance appraisals by the supervisor of the organisation. The grade for the internship is based on the individual internship report, the performance of the student, and reflection of the student on his/her internship activities. Content Students can choose between a practical assignment, a research assignment, or a combination of these assignments. Most students opt for a practical assignment in an organisation. In a practical assignment, the main purpose is to familiarise oneself with the occupational practice in the field, such as consultancy, HRM, training, coaching, recruitment and selection. The purpose of a research assignment is to conduct research in the field of Work and Organisational Psychology. Brenninkmeijer. She can be contacted via masterA&O@uu.nl.

lecturers: ['drs. S.B. Soeparman', 'prof. dr. ir. A.G. van der Lippe']
text:
Course goals The internship will enable students to:
 
  • Gather empirical data for the masterthesis
  • Link academic theory to practice
  • Apply knowledge, skills and experience to a work environment
  • Demonstrate professional skills in the workplace
  • Build and maintain positive professional relationships
  • Demonstrate awareness of issues that are specific to a certain policy field, institutional environment or organization
  • Develop self-understanding, self-discipline, reflective capabilities, maturity and confidence
  • Develop strong networking/mentoring relationships within a professional and potential future work environment. 
Together, the internship and labour market preparation (course code 201600012) and the Master's thesis (course code 201600013) form a whole and are worth a total of 30 credits. 

The internship is designed to receive experience in applying theories learned in the curriculum to specific professional contexts.The internship will heighten students awareness of  issues that are specific to a certain professional environment or policy field. The internship is an opportunity to not only use and develop knowledge and skills that are specific to the internship organization, but also to enhance some of the skills that are transferable to any professional work setting. The internship can give you valuable information in making decisions about the direction of future studies or employment.

In principle, the internship and policy research will take place in combination. This can only be waived in exceptional cases. Agreement about the policy research to be undertaken will take place at the beginning of the internship and a suitable supervisor will be assigned. A project plan and a strict timetable will be discussed with the assigned supervisor.

During the internship students are expected to gather empirical data with which to write their master thesis.

Completing the Masters programme in Sociology: contemporary social problems provides students with:
 
Knowledge and understanding in the area of defining problems, theories, research and policy:
1c            Scientific and field practice developments within a social sector or organisation.
1d           The key characteristics of different domain-specific areas and problem contexts.
 
Application of knowledge and understanding.
2a           Analyse complex questions from a sociological/interdisciplinary/comparative theoretical perspective and relate these to scientific and social debates.
2b           Translate/apply new and previously acquired socio-scientific knowledge to current social issues.
2e           Carry out independent research, draw conclusions from it in written and spoken form in a clear, straightforward manner to present to an audience of specialists and non-specialists.
2f            Create a link between scientific knowledge, research questions and practical issues.
2g           Provide a client with responsible advice on policy or organisation.
 
Form judgements about scientific­, societal and ethical aspects.
3a           Reflect on developments and discussions in science and society with regard to current social issues, on the basis of well-founded theoretical, analytical, methodological and practice-oriented considerations.
3b           Critically reflect upon information they have gathered themselves on current social issues based on theoretical, methodological, practice-oriented and social considerations.
3c            Adopt an honest and critical position in relation to research plans and results.
3e           Think critically about the professional ethics of people working in sociology within a wide social context.
3f            Think critically about the professional ethics of actors in the future professional field.
3g           Make a sound assessment of the scientific quality of proposed measures and of the organisational, political and administrative and social practicality of the policy and organisation advice formulated.
 
Communication.
4a           Report, independently and in an academically sound way, on their own activities and present clear recommendations to interested parties both verbally and in writing.
4b           Skilful communication and interaction with colleagues and others working in the future professional field.
4c            Report the results of their own research, or advice, to clients or others working in the field verbally and in writing in a clear and structured manner.
4d           Critique and comment on reports by fellow students, others working in the field, colleagues and clients in a constructive manner.
 
Learning skills.
5a           Reflect on the development of their professional identity and take action on this by developing their own competencies (lifelong learning).
5b           Reflect upon professional ethical issues within their future professional field.
5c            Deal with ethical aspects in a well-considered manner as an academic professional.
5d           Be part of the social context, taking into account the parties concerned and thus deal with them with integrity and in a scientific and professional manner.
5e           Work independently in professional practice.
5f            Collaborate with professionals from other scientific disciplines.

course_title: Internship in a museum abroad (for Dutch students) or in the Netherlands (for students from abroad)
lecturers: ['C.A. van Rijn', 'dr. E.F. Koldeweij', 'dr. H. Bavelaar', 'dr. S.J. Moran', 'dr. V.M. Schmidt', 'P.F. Vlaardingerbroek', 'prof. dr. M.A. Weststeijn', 'prof. dr. M.W. Kwakkelstein', 'prof. dr. S.G.M. Dupré']
text:
Content The internship (or placement) in this RMA is intended as a working experience in a major art museum. The internship should have a strong research focus. This can be obtained by working on the permanent collection of a museum, or in the context of the preparation of an exhibition.
Dutch students usually go abroad, while students from elsewhere usually find a place in one of the major Dutch or Flemish institutions. In recent years, Dutch students went to the U.K., Germany or Ireland, although some have reached out as far as Japan. In the Netherlands, students were accommodated in Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen, the Rijksmuseum, and the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam. In Flanders, the museums in Bruges in Antwerp offer good opportunities.
As an alternative, students can take research seminars or tutorials at an advanced level at other universities in Europe or the US. The alternative has to be approved by the programme coordinator.

lecturers: ['A. Turro Sol', 'dr. A.M. van Uden, MSc', 'dr. J.P.C. Rigtering', 'dr. L.A. de Bell', 'dr. P. Darnihamedani', 'dr. P. Fliers', 'dr. S. Goubitz', 'drs. A.J.C.M. van Hoof', 'drs. H.A. de Graaf', 'J.H.J. Lukkezen', 'dr. Y.K. Grift']
text:
Course goals Learning Objectives:
 
1.    Learn to apply and extend knowledge and skills gained during theory classes.
2.    Learn to translate business management problems into a clear problem statement and relevant sub questions.
3.    Learn to design and conduct the practical and theoretical research needed to answer the questions.
4.    Learn to analyse and interpret results.
5.    Learn to write a business report with concrete conclusions and recommendations.
6.    Learn to present the outcomes of the report to an audience of specialists and non-specialists.
7.    Learn how to work in a professional environment.
 
 
Content
To really understand how things work outside the university, an internship in a company or institute is obligatory. Preferably the topic of the internship is a combination of both business and science. Before the start of the internship a clear formulation of a problem, which will be the subject of investigation, has to be approved by the internship coordinator. The internship includes practical work, and a report (in total around 5 months), for instance with a consultancy firm advising multinationals on their research policies, or in a small biotech start-up company working on business development. A supervisor from the University should be involved in guiding you through this business internship.

course_title: Internship: Clinical and health psychology, track health promotion
lecturers: ['A. Vedder, MSc', 'A. Zwarts-Engelbert', 'A.A. van Elburg', 'D. Cath', 'Docenten van de afdeling/departement(en)', 'dr. M. Vollmann', 'dr. M.M. Rijkeboer', 'dr. S. Doosje', 'dr. S. van Linden', 'drs. E.C.B. Verspui', 'drs. J.M. Versteeg', 'L.C. Sternheim, PhD', 'prof. dr. M.A. van den Hout', 'prof. dr. R. Geenen']
text:
Course goals
Students are primarily responsible for finding and being accepted by a suitable internship organisation. 

After completing the internship, students will have:
  • demonstrated the ability to integrate previously learned theory, methodologies and empirical knowledge into experiences in practice at the organisation;
  • acquired skills for future professional practice;
  • developed a professional and academic working attitude;
  • learned to reflect on the internship and their academic, ethical and personal experiences;
  • acquired and shared new knowledge for the benefit of the internship organisation and their own development;
  • learned to report on work activities and their own academic, professional and personal development in a concise and professional manner;
  • explicitly and personally familiarised themselves with the job market of the future.
The internship report is the most important assessment of the students' academic, professional and personal development, in which they describe their experiences with and reflections on the internship. The level of academic, ethical, professional and personal reflection demonstrated in the report is a key element of the assessment. The internship report will be assessed by the lecturer responsible for internships and an independent second assessor, after the internship supervisor from the organisation has checked the validity of the statements therein. The student's professional development is guided by means of peer review and supervision meetings, interim and final evaluations. In the internship supervisor's final evaluation, the supervisor provides a recommended mark that helps to determine the final mark. Students are primarily responsible for their own professional development, assisted by contributions from fellow students, the lecturer and the internship supervisor. In the internship report, students demonstrate their ability to provide a concise and reflective description of their activities during the internship and their resulting professional development.
Content
The internship is a study component in which students do an active professional internship in the field of clinical psychology or health promotion. During the internship, students learn to integrate theory, empirical knowledge, methodologies and their other academic skills into professional practice. It is important for Master's students to learn to reflect on their academic, professional and personal qualities. As a future professional, students are expected to demonstrate considerable self-management skills and be clearly oriented towards the job market. Students in the Health Promotion track will do their internship at an organisation in the field of promoting good health, such as the Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu, RIVM, the Netherlands Nutrition Centre, the local Community Health Service (Gemeentelijke Gezondheidsdienst, GGD) or first-line basic healthcare institutions (e.g. general practitioners). 
The Health Promotion track offers the opportunity to do either a practical internship or a research internship. During a practical internship, students gain experience with prevention, treatment or policymaking activities within health promotion or clinical psychology. Such activities consist of participating in providing information, training, and interventions in the field of health promotion and preventive measures. Students thereby gain experience using psychological strategies in the field of preventive measures and behavioural changes, as well as with designing, implementing and evaluating interventions for promoting good health. The research internship is intended for students wishing to familiarise themselves explicitly with research-related activities. Students actively participate in an ongoing health promotion-related research project at an organisation, gaining experience with professional and academic skills connected to different phases of the empirical cycle, such as literature review, data collection, data analysis and reporting research results. Students are supervised by an experienced academic professional within the organisation.

lecturers: ['drs. A.J. Westermann', 'drs. E. Laroes', 'drs. M.T. Mainhard']
text:
Course goals Aan het eind van de cursus:
  • ben je in staat om interpersoonlijke processen te benoemen en te duiden volgens het begrippenkader van de interpersoonlijke theorie;
  • ben je je bewust van het interpersoonlijk effect van je eigen gedrag in de klas;
  • kun je eigen gedrag en dat van anderen analyseren en gedragsalternatieven formuleren;
  • heb je je gedragsrepertoire uitgebreid.
Content Wat er in de klas gebeurt kan vanuit verschillende oogpunten worden beschreven, bijvoorbeeld:
Welke kennis komt aan bod? Welke leeractiviteiten? Maar ook: wat gebeurt er interpersoonlijk tussen docent en leerlingen? Interpersoonlijke processen in de klas hangen aan de ene kant samen met leeropbrengsten van leerlingen (hoe goed presteren leerlingen, maar ook hoe leuk vinden leerlingen een vak) en aan de andere kant met opbrengsten van docenten. Hoeveel stress ervaren docenten en hoe gemotiveerd zijn zij voor hun berope? Basisbeginsel van het interpersoonlijke perspectief is dat een klas een sociaal systeem is, waarin docent en leerlingen elkaars gedrag wederzijds beïnvloeden en dat al het gedrag dat een docent in de klas vertoont een interpersoonlijke betekenis heeft. Deze betekenis beschrijven we met de mate van invloed van een docent (d.w.z. dominantie of sturing) en de mate van nabijheid (de warmte in het contact met leerlingen).
In dit keuzevak wordt een begrippenkader aangereikt waarmee interpersoonlijke aspecten van lesgeven, zoals relaties met leerlingen en interactie in de klas kunnen worden beschreven.
Studenten leren de wetmatigheden van interpersoonlijke processen kennen en leren hun gedrag als instrument in de klas in te zetten. We leggen uit waarom je wél moet 'lachen voor de kerst'.

NB: Voor deelname aan deze cursus is het noodzakelijk dat je gedurende de cursusperiode toegang hebt tot een vo-klas (als stagiair of docent)!

Course goals Gaining knowledge of the most important theories and empirical research on interpersonal processes. Conducting a literature search on a specific theme within the domain of interpersonal processes. Applying social psychological theories on a societal problem and developing interventions from a social psychological perspective. Gaining knowledge of and insight in conflict management. Content
Binnen deze cursus worden theorieën en onderzoek behandeld op het gebied van 1) partnerrelaties en 2) conflicthantering en mediation. Binnen het thema partnerrelaties gaan we in op de vraag waarom mensen relaties met anderen aangaan. Vervolgens behandelen we factoren die bepalen wat nu precies aantrekkelijk is aan een partner, hoe mensen omgaan met potentiele bedreigingen voor hun relatie (zoals conflicten en aantrekkelijke anderen), en zullen we ingaan op de vraag hoe een goede relatie zich onderscheidt van een slechte relatie. Het tweede deel van de cursus richt zich op conflicthantering, onderhandelen en mediation. Studenten leren over hun eigen karakteristieke manier van reageren in conflictsituaties (conflictstijl). Daarnaast wordt ingegaan op verschillende theoretische modellen die bij de verklaring van (het ontstaan en escalatie van) conflicten worden gebruikt. Tot slot wordt ingegaan op mediation en het handelen van de professional die ingrijpt in en assisteert bij de hantering van conflicten van anderen.

Content Voorbereidend op de afstudeerfase wordt binnen deze cursus aandacht besteed aan een aantal aspecten rondom het opzetten van wetenschappelijk onderzoek, met aandacht voor implementatie van de resultaten in de klinische praktijk, resultaten van wetenschappelijk onderzoek te interpreteren en overtuigend te communiceren over onderzoeksplannen, opzet en resultaten.
Er wordt aan de hand van een bestaande recente dataset aandacht besteed aan datamanagement, -analyse en –interpretatie. Daarnaast komt de systematiek rondom implementatie aan de orde, hierbij wordt gebruik gemaakt van implementatieprojecten uit de dagelijkse praktijk van het Koninklijk Genootschap voor Fysiotherapie (KNGF). Tot slot wordt aandacht besteed aan opinievorming en kritisch reflecteren op maatschappelijk relevante thema’s in de vorm van een debat.

Course goals
Na afloop van dit college:
·        Heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in de geschiedenisvan relaties tussen Moslims en Christenen in Europa;
·        Heeft de student een theoretisch-analytisch kader om verschillende vormen van interreligieuze relaties te duiden
·        Kan de student actuele interreligieuze verhoudingen tussen Islam en Christendom interpreteren vanuit historische ontwikkelingen
·        Heeft de student inzicht in actuele moeilijkheden en mogelijkheden van interreligieuze relaties tussen Islam en Christendom;
·        Heeft de student kennis gemaakt met de praktijk van interreligieuze dialoog in Nederland
·         
Content

Het eerste deel van de cursus behandelt de verhoudingen tussen christendom en islam in historisch perspectief, met een focus op Europa. Daarbij besteden we  aandacht aan de geschiedenis van de beeldvorming tussen beide religies. Het tweede deel van de cursus behandelt actuele thema's in de relaties tussen beide godsdiensten, zoals de impact van de clash of civilizations-these op interreligieuze beeldvorming en initiatieven in interreligieuze dialoog, het Nederlandse Islamdebat. Het derde deel van de cursus gaat in op de hedendaagse praktijk van de interreligieuze dialoog in Nederland.

lecturers: ['dr. L. van Weelden', 'dr. M. Struiksma', 'dr. M.M. Jongenelen', 'prof. dr. L.R. Lentz']
text:
Course goals De student kan:
- vanuit een academische attitude kennisclaims beoordelen;
- professioneel optreden in organisaties;
- kan communicatieproblemen van organisaties en medewerkers onderzoeken en analyseren;
- kan communicatieproblemen vertalen in concrete ontwerp- en adviesvragen;
- communicatieproducten ontwerpen met gebruikmaking van de laatste stand van onderzoek;
- communicatie-interventies ontwerpen en implementeren en op effectiviteit onderzoeken.
Content Tijdens het interventieonderzoek werkt de student aan een verbetertraject op het terrein van documentontwerp of communicatieprocessen. Het verbetertraject vindt plaats in de organisatie waar ook de stage wordt gelopen. Eerst wordt op basis van een probleemanalyse een interventie ontwikkeld en geïmplementeerd die is afgestemd op de organisatiecontext; vervolgens wordt het effect van deze interventie onderzocht.

Arbeidsmarktoriëntatie:
Het doen van toegepast onderzoek in een organisatie en het adviseren op basis daarvan is een van de kerncompetenties van de academische communicatieprofessional.

course_title: Intervention in families, school and neighbourhood
lecturers: ['Docenten van de afdeling/departement(en)', 'dr. S.F. Mulder', 'drs. H. ten Kate', 'Hiemstra, MSc']
text:
Course goals Studenten die de cursus gevolgd hebben:
  • beschikken over kennis m.b.t. welke aspecten van de gezin- en schoolcontext gerelateerd zijn aan de ontwikkeling van gedrag bij kinderen, uitgaande van de huidige ontwikkelingen in het werkveld
  • kunnen theoretische kennis vertalen naar de praktijk van ondersteuning van individuen en systemen
  • weten welke interventies je kan toepassen binnen gezin, school en buurt en kunnen beredeneren in welke situatie een bepaalde interventie toepasbaar is
  • kunnen technieken selecteren en toepassen om problemen in het sociaal emotioneel functioneren in een klas of gezinssituatie te veranderen
  • weten wat werkzame en/of effectieve elementen van interventies zijn met betrekking tot  school, gezin en buurt
  • weten hoe de verschillende systemen zich tot elkaar verhouden

Relatie tussen de toetsen en leerdoelen
In de toetsen komen de volgende doelen aan bod:
  • het beschikken over kennis m.b.t. welke aspecten van de gezin- en schoolcontext gerelateerd zijn aan de ontwikkeling van gedrag bij kinderen, uitgaande van de huidige ontwikkelingen in het werkveld
  • het kunnen vertalen van theoretische kennis naar de praktijk van ondersteuning van individuen en systemen
  • weten welke interventies je kan toepassen binnen gezin, school en buurt en kunnen beredeneren in welke situatie een bepaalde interventie toepasbaar is
  • weten wat werkzame en/of effectieve elementen van interventies zijn met betrekking tot  school, gezin en buurt
  • weten hoe de verschillende systemen zich tot elkaar verhouden
In de werkgroep komt het volgende doel vooral aan bod:
  • het kunnen selecteren en toepassen van technieken om problemen in het sociaal emotioneel functioneren in een klas of gezinssituatie te veranderen
Content Hoorcolleges waarin o.a. de volgende onderwerpen aan bod komen:
  • school: school- en klassenklimaat, klassenmanagement en effectieve interventies
  • residentiële settings: leefklimaat op groep en effectieve interventies
  • interacties en opvoeding in het gezin: ouders en kinderen, broers en zussen en effectieve interventies
  • de buurt: invloed van peergroep en buurt op opgroeien en ontwikkeling en hierbij de effectieve interventies
Literatuurstudie waarin stof centraal staat die aansluit bij de genoemde hoorcolleges en die bruikbaar is bij de opdrachten.
 
Werkgroepen waarin gewerkt wordt aan opdrachten aangaande:
  • oefenen met technieken om problemen in de verschillende contexten aan te pakken
  • interventies in de verschillende contexten
Huiswerkopdrachten worden gebruikt om tussentijds te toetsen of studenten zich de aangeboden technieken en kennis eigen hebben gemaakt en hier op kunnen reflecteren. De huiswerkopdrachten worden overwegend zelfstandig of in groepjes van twee studenten gemaakt en ingeleverd bij de werkgroepdocent.

Eindopdracht. Deze wordt door de student ingeleverd en beoordeeld door de werkgroepdocent.

Course goals
Important note about language
The language of instruction in this internship program is Dutch.
  • Knowledge and insight in learning processes, group processes, behavior change, psychological intervention approaches, evidence-based intervening, training design, training delivery, communication- and coaching skills, and professional ethics for psychologists;
  • Training design: designing a workshop on study skills in collaboration with a co-trainer; contribution to the design of an e-learning program;
  • Training delivery: providing training in study skills and professional communication skills in an academic context;
  • Peer coaching: applying goal focused and solution focused coaching skills, feedback conversations, peer supervision;
  • Competence development: improvement on core conceptual, technical and (inter)personal competencies as an intervention psychologist; becoming an academic professional;
  • Personal and professional reflection on work performance and learning progress;
  • Team work: professional collaboration and working and learning in a team;
  • Career orientation: finding a personal mentor; organizing a company visit; guest lectures, developing a career identity.
Relationship between learning goals and assessment
The overall and individual learning objectives of the internship should be addressed during internship meetings and in the internship report. To determine the final grade for the internship the supervisor assesses the trainee’s work performance (e. g. participation in and contribution to meetings; student evaluations) and learning progress (reflected in internship activities and in the internship report).
  Content The ‘Intervention Psychology Internship Program’ is unique compared to other internships, because of the:
  • Autonomy in providing training and experimenting with group interventions (an opportunity one rarely gets as a trainee at a training or consultancy company);
  • Intensive and substantive personal and technical training and supervision during the internship;
  • Intensive collaboration with other master students, who are also in the internship program: an important professional network for the future;
  • Focus on career orientation and the development of a career identity;
  • Access to the PION-network (Psychologists and Interventions in Organizations Network; www.pion-netwerk.nl), a professional network of ex-trainees of the ‘Intervention Psychology Internship Program’;
  • Access to the EFPSA network (European Federation of Psychology Students’ Association; www.efpsa.org), a professional network of (student) training psychologists. 
The ‘Intervention Psychology Internship Program’ has proven to provide master students with good employment prospects in the area of skills training, coaching, consultancy, teaching, human resource development, management traineeships in organizations.
 
The ‘Intervention Psychology Internship Program’ is accessible to approximately twelve master students, who are enrolled in the master ‘Social, Health and Organizational Psychology’. The internship program consists of:
  1. A preparatory phase (1st semester; 5 ECTS), which is run in groups and consists of:
 
  • Participating in the Train-the-Trainer Summer school in the pre-master week (late August / early September 2017). This summer school is organized in collaboration with EFPSA (www.efpsa.org). The main objective of the summer school is training design, both theory and application.
  • Participating in the 'Train-the-Trainer Intervention Psychology’ course in teaching period 2. This course is only open to master students who are accepted for the intervention program. This course teaches trainees the necessary knowledge and skills to provide training in professional communication skills to bachelor students in the second semester.
  • Completing a personal challenge (to be explained in more detail during the internship program)
2. The actual internship phase (2nd semester; 15 ECTS), which consists of:
 
  • Providing training in professional communication skills within one variant of the bachelor course ‘Professional communication skills’ in teaching period 3 (variant Clinical Psychology or variant Neuropsychology) and in another variant of this course in teaching period 4 (variant Social, Health and Organizational Psychology or variant Child and Adolescent Psychology).
  • Attending guided technical supervision meetings and guided personal supervision meetings during teaching period 3 and 4. In preparation for and during the guided supervision meetings trainees reflect on their work performance and learning progress in the internship program.
  • Organizing company visits for bachelor students within the bachelor course ‘Coaching and Consulting Psychology’ in teaching period 3. Trainees should regard these visits as an opportunity for career orientation.
  • Completing a personal challenge (to be explained in more detail during the internship program)
  • Writing an internship report in accordance with the guidelines for such report drawn up for the master ‘Social, Health and Organizational Psychology’.
Students interested in the ‘Intervention Psychology Internship Program’ should contact Richta IJntema at r.ijntema@uu.nl.

course_title: Interventions and Policies I: Practice Orientation
lecturers: ['dr. D.A. Lepianka', 'dr. G.W.J.M. Stevens', 'dr. M. Peeters', 'prof. dr. J.B.F. de Wit']
text:
Course goals
  1. Upon completion of the course ‘Interventions and policies 1’ the student has an understanding of and can reflect upon the important concepts regarding the development and implementation processes of social policies and interventions;
  2. Upon completion of the course ‘Interventions and policies 1’ the student can reflect upon the different perspectives about the development and implementation process of social policies and interventions of a) politicians and policy makers, b) science, c) professional practice, and d) clients / target groups;
  3. Upon completion of the course ‘Interventions and policies 1’ the student can provide examples of social policies and interventions on a local, national and international level within three social domains: 1) labour, care and wellbeing, 2) youth and family, and 3) diversity and integration.
  4. Upon completion of the course ‘Interventions and policies 1’ students have an understanding of and can apply the basic assumptions behind and different viewpoints of the decentralization/transformation of the social domains;
  5. Upon completion of the course ‘Interventions and policies 1’students can build up an argumentation about how the decentralization/transformation of the social domains may impact the development and implementation processes of social policies and interventions.,
The different goals of the course are addressed in the (guest)lectures (goals 1-5), tutorials (goals 1-5) and readings (1-5). In the exam, all goals are tested. In the paper students are requested to apply their knowledge about goals 1 and 2 and to an example of a social policy or intervention (goals 3).
  Content In this course students get acquainted with central concepts and theoretical perspectives on the development and implementation of social policies and interventions on a local, national and international level as well as the interplay between social policies and interventions. Different approaches to social policies and interventions are presented and implementation issues discussed. Throughout the course it becomes clear that the development and implementation of social policies and interventions does not take place in a (social) vacuum. Prevailing (local, national and international) political perspectives influence the specific approaches chosen for social policies and interventions. Science, professionals and target groups have their role in the development of social policies and interventions or encourage/discourage the successful implementation of social policies and interventions. To illustrate these general processes several examples from for instance health and education, income and employment are discussed throughout all lectures. One ‘big’ issue in the social domain is the transformation/decentralisation of the social domain, which will also be the discussed elaborately. Among others, the central ideas behind the transformations/decentralisations and the (expected) consequences for governance, social policy (implementation and effectiveness) and target populations are discussed.

course_title: Interventions and Policies II: Research Orientation
text:
Course goals Students following this course will learn to:
 
  • develop an understanding of the different stages of the ‘policy and intervention cycle’ and the role of social research; Are able to translate interventions and policy into measurable program theories;
  • Have insight into the different methods of evaluation research and the circumstances in which these methods are used;
  • Have insight into the possibilities and limitations of different methods;
  • Are able to choose the most suitable method of evaluation research in practical situations.
 
  Content Behavioral interventions and social policy programs are developed to prevent social problems from occurring or to solve them, and/or to improve the situation of vulnerable groups. However, in practice interventions and policies do not always work as intended. In order to be successful interventions and policies have to be implemented in neighborhoods, schools, families, under the supervision of professionals working as case managers, youth worker or social worker. Yet the objectives of policymakers and professionals can diverge and during the implementation of behavioral interventions and social policy programs many problems can occur. First, policymakers and professionals encounter all sorts of practical problems, like erroneous assumptions, problems with the organizations that should administer the programs, overburdened or unwilling professionals, or a lack of cooperation between various stakeholders – to name only a few. Second, when trying to establish the effectiveness of interventions and policies researchers encounter all sorts of research problems, like unsuitable research methods, defective implementation of the research plan, or an erroneous analysis and/or interpretation of the research results. It is in the interest of society, and more particularly of vulnerable groups, that interventions and policies are successful, that no public money is wasted, and that individuals are get the help or support they need, or that the social conditions in neighborhoods are improved.  
 
This course – which is part of the master-program “Social Policies and Social Interventions” (SPSI) – focuses particularly on the research problems that can occur in evaluating policies and interventions, taking into account the social context in which this takes place. The course enables students to develop an understanding of the various types of social policy and intervention research. In the course special attention is paid to the difficult conditions under which evaluation research often takes place, the choices that have to be made in such circumstances, and the role of the social scientist in researching the effects of social policy and interventions.  The course focuses on the following, interrelated questions: (a) how can you decide whether or not a particular form of social intervention has the desired impact?; and (b) why do some forms of social intervention have the desired effect while others do not? Students will learn about the various types of complementary evaluation research – randomized controlled trials (RCTs), quasi-experimental research as well as qualitative and mixed-method research – that contribute to an answer to both of these questions. During the course, students learn to formulate a ‘program theory’ about how and in what situations they expect a particular intervention to be effective. Furthermore, it is discussed in what different ways the impact and  effectiveness of social policies and interventions can be tested; potential advantages and limitations of different research methods are considered. The knowledge obtained and skills learned during this course enable students to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions and to give recommendations for improvement.
 


Academic skills
The following academic competencies will be tested in this course:
•        methodological skills aimed at identifying and evaluating the mechanisms associated with social issues (‘problem definition’) and with social policy and interventions (‘policy or program theory’);
•        skills in setting up evaluation research;
•        skills in assessing the benefits and limitations of different kinds of evaluation research.

Course goals
Kennis van sociaal-psychologischetheorieën en empirische onderzoeken die inzicht verschaffen in intra- en intergroepsprocessen.
  • Ervaring met het zelfstandig uitvoeren van een literatuurverkenning rondom een specifiek thema op het gebied van groepsprocessen en hierover een onderzoeksvoorstel kunnen presenteren en verantwoorden.
  • Inzicht en vaardigheden met betrekking tot de diagnostiek van processen binnen en tussen groepen en de ontwikkeling (stagnatie) daarvan.
  • Inzicht in de eigen assumpties m.b.t. menselijke samenwerking, de consequenties voor het eigen gedrag en de positie in groepen.
Relatie tussen de toetsen en leerdoelen
  • Toetsing vindt plaats middels een meerkeuzetoets aan het einde van het vak en een groepsverslag. Met de meerkeuzetoets zal worden gemeten of studenten over de kerninhoud van de cursus beschikken door zo breed mogelijk naar de inhoud van de cursus te vragen. De toepassing van de inhoud en het vermogen van studenten het geleerde zelfstandig ter oplossing van een daadwerkelijk maatschappelijk probleem te gebruiken wordt dan nog met het groepsverslag getoetst. Ten slotte schrijven studenten nog een korte evaluatie van de cursus waarin ze hun eigen ervaring van de groepsprocessen tijdens de werkgroepen toe moeten lichten, waarmee dan alle drie de hoofddoelen van de cursus getoetst gaan worden.
Content
In de colleges wordt op basis van sociaal-psychologische theorieën en empirisch onderzoek achtereenvolgens aandacht besteed aan de entree in groepen en groepslidmaatschap, invloed en macht in groepen (polarisatie) en intergroepsrelaties (afhankelijkheid en identiteit).
De inhoud van de werkgroepen is tweeledig: 1) studenten zullen begeleid worden in het ontwikkelen, presenteren en verdedigen van eigen advies en onderzoeksideeën op het gebied van groepsprocessen; 2) studenten zullen intra- en intergroepsprocessen zelf ervaren, aangezien de werkgroepen voor een groot deel zelfsturend zijn, en leren hoe deze te interpreteren.

college: Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance
text:
Content Entrepreneurship is usually associated with start-up activities by independent entrepreneurs. However, entrepreneurial activity can also take place within established organisations. Entrepreneurial employees are those who take initiative and hands-on responsibility for creating innovation and change within existing organisations. It can result in a variety of outcomes ranging from internal process innovation, service innovation, and product innovation to new venture creation, either inside or outside the organisational domain. Entrepreneurial activity by employees is usually referred to as ‘intrapreneurship’. Increasingly, top managers and scholars recognize that, next to their regular tasks and routine work, these intrapreneurial efforts by employees are crucial for the long-term prosperity and profitability of a firm.
 
This course is addressed to students interested in exploring the challenges of facilitating and sustaining intrapreneurship in large organisations. From a theoretical as well as practitioner point of view, these challenges are interesting as they contain fundamental questions relating to risk and reward functions within organisations and strategic versus unplanned modes of organisational change. In the course we adopt a multilevel perspective that pertains to the individual à organisational (bottom-up) and organisational à individual (top-down) relationships to analyse such questions.
 
The course contains the state-of-the-art in academic research pertaining to core topics in intrapreneurship like: bottom-up innovation, (macro)conditions for intrapreneurship, and promoting/facilitating intrapreneurship. Special attention will be paid to the multilevel complexity of managing intrapreneurship. The course follows an experiential learning format. This implies that student’s knowledge is advanced by means of case studies, assignments related to an intrapreneurship project, and interaction with practitioners, all adding to a series of lectures. In addition, one week will be devoted to the methodological techniques and skills that are relevant for the project.
 
Learning objectives
This course is designed to provide academic knowledge on the development, and management of intrapreneurship. The major course objectives include:
  • Analysing the organisational context in which intrapreneurs operate;  
  • Analysing risk – reward structures within an organisation;
  • Evaluating strategic substitutes relating to planned versus unplanned modes of organisational change within an organisation;
  • Evaluating potential managerial interventions relating to intrapreneurship within a complex system by creating an intrapreneurship action plan for a management team;
  • Evaluating the managerial skills needed to facilitate intrapreneurship within a complex system by creating an intrapreneurship action plan for a management team.
The learning objectives necessitate that students understand intrapreneurship in relation to economic conditions, sectors, competition between firms, and technological developments or societal change. In addition, students should be able to address limits and shortcomings of the associated managerial techniques.
 
Format
Experiential learning is the process of learning through experience and reflection. It therefore requires that the student takes on an active role. Next to interactive lectures, the course therefore has a strong focus on project work in which the learning through experience and reflection plays a major role. The main elements of the course are described in more detail below.
  • Interactive lectures: This course is an interactive and participatory course that teaches the key concepts and theories during the lectures. Active participation and discussion are stimulated to advance the knowledge and understanding of the students. Students are expected to prepare the interactive lectures well by preparing and reading the articles and case studies in advance.
  • Intrapreneurship group project: Experiential learning is achieved through an intrapreneurship case study project. During this project, students apply their knowledge gained via the interactive lectures by analysing a ‘real world’ intrapreneurship case. In addition, they need to actively expand knowledge base in certain area’s depending on case specific characteristics. Successfully completing the intrapreneurship project requires students to collaborate with the organisation and to have frequent interactions with the organisational members in order to build a comprehensive understanding of the context and mechanisms that influence intrapreneurial behaviour with the organisation.
Assessment method
The assessment is based upon two different sub-parts:
  • Action plan: includes problem formalization and proposed research methodology (In total 35% of the final grade. The grade consists of a group grade [50%] and individual grade [50%]);
  • Intrapreneurship project: includes problem or case analysis and recommendations (In total 65% of the final grade. The grade consists of a group grade [50%] and individual grade [50%]).
